item.title: An Afghan Gathering Steeped in Tradition, and Consent
item.description: The loya jirga taking place in Afghanistan is part of a venerable institution in which representatives of Afghan tribes discuss issues of concern.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Margaret Horwath for The New York Times
item.media:description: A grand council of Afghan leaders, the loya jirga, assembled in Kabul in 1956. The council has been around for hundreds of years.

item.title: India Ink: Newsmagazine’s Handling of Sex Harassment Complaint Draws Criticism
item.description: After a reporter accused her editor in chief of sexual assault, women’s rights activists expressed outrage that the newsmagazine was treating the complaint as an internal matter.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Tarun Tejpal, editor in chief of Tehelka newsmagazine, addressing a press conference in New Delhi on Oct. 25, 2007.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Lu Xun Letter Sold for More Than $1 Million
item.description: A letter that Lu Xun, one of China’s most venerated writers, wrote to a friend in 1934 sold for about three times its asking price.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: 3 Women Rescued in British Slavery Case
item.description: Three women have been rescued from a London home after one called a charity to say she had been held against her will for more than three decades, British police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Typhoon Reignites Debate Over How U.S. Supplies Food Aid
item.description: The Obama administration and some lawmakers say the disaster in the Philippines underscores the need for flexibility to buy less expensive food closer to the areas where disasters occur.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Greek Budget Forecasts Growth, but Skeptics Abound
item.description: An economic blueprint based on optimism is subject to revision by creditors, who say Athens still needs to find ways to bridge its budget gap.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Speech by Iran’s Supreme Leader Raises Ire as Talks Resume
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei assailed Israel, the United States and France in televised remarks before international negotiators met again in Geneva to discuss Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Turkey, Its Allies Floundering, Tempers Its Ambitions to Lead Region
item.description: With the Muslim Brotherhood on the run in Egypt, some in Turkey would now settle for just getting along with its neighbors.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 21
item.description: Women awaiting the arrival of Rahul Gandhi, vice president of Congress party, for an election rally in Mizoram.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women, in Kolasib district of Mizoram, awaiting the arrival of Rahul Gandhi, vice president of Congress party, for an election rally in the state.

item.title: Nepal’s Maoists, Losing Vote, Charge Election Fraud
item.description: The leader of the Himalayan country’s largest Maoist party demanded a suspension of vote tallying and threatened to rejoin hard-liners.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Ukraine Refuses to Free Ex-Leader, Raising Concerns Over E.U. Talks
item.description: Parliament rejected legislation that would have let the jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, seek medical treatment in Germany.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: At Least 32 Killed as Truck Explodes at Iraqi Market
item.description: The blast at a fruit and vegetable market in Saadiya, north of Baghdad, came a day after a wave of explosions that convulsed the capital.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A bomb exploded in a cafe in the Shiite neighborhood of Baya in Baghdad, where young people gather to smoke hookahs, killing five youths and wounding 10 others, a police official said.

item.title: Karzai Says Security Pact With U.S. Should Be Signed Next Year
item.description: On a day a council of Afghan leaders had gathered to weigh the deal, President Hamid Karzai’s comments again threaten a long-term security agreement.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Leaders attended the loya jirga on Thursday in Kabul.

item.title: Drone Strike Reported Outside Pakistan’s Tribal Region
item.description: The attack, which is said to have killed Haqqani militants, comes during a stretch of growing political outrage over C.I.A. airstrikes in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: India Ink: India Prepares Evacuations of 100,000 Before Cyclone Helen Hits
item.description: The cyclone is expected to make landfall in Andhra Pradesh by Friday evening.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: A beach in Visakhapatnam district, in Andhra Pradesh, on Oct. 12, as Cyclone Phailin neared the coast of India.

item.title: China’s Highest Court Seeks to Curtail Abuses of Justice
item.description: The court issued demands that judges bar confessions obtained through torture and avoid applying the death penalty when the evidence is shaky.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Tory Icon Decries Class Privilege in Britain
item.description: Sir John Major has grabbed headlines by assailing growing imbalances in British society, bemoaning the hardships facing hard-working “silent have-nots.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The former British prime minister John Major.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: On the Roach to Riches
item.description: Some Chinese farmers have found a potentially lucrative business in raising cockroaches.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Some eat cockroaches, but Mr. Wang also cites their medicinal uses.

item.title: Tacloban Residents Describe Frenzied Dash for Goods
item.description: The looters justified their actions as the product of a desperate situation after their city had been hit by Typhoon Haiyan.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robinsons Department Store in Tacloban was ransacked by looters in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan.

item.title: Britain Investigates Reports of Citizens’ Deaths in Syria
item.description: The British Foreign Office is looking into reports that four Britons died while fighting on the side of Islamic militants opposed to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Labor Camp Prisoners Are Released, Questions Remain
item.description: Local governments in Shanghai and Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, announced earlier this week that they had released all the people previously held at their “re-education through labor” camps.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: A re-education through labor camp in Hunan Province.

item.title: Suspect Held in Shooting at a Paris Newspaper
item.description: Officials say the man arrested served four years in prison for his role as an accomplice in the shooting deaths of three police officers and a taxi driver in 1994.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Prosecutors Detail Bid to Sway South Korean Election
item.description: South Korean politics have been rocked by accusations that the country’s spy agency conducted an online campaign to help elect Park Geun-hye president.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author Gaiutra Bahadur
item.description: Ms. Bahardur spoke about the story of her great-grandmother, an indentured woman, which forms the crux of her new book.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Gaiutra Bahadur, author of the book 'Coolie Woman.'

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Property Taxes Hoped to Curb China’s Real Estate Excesses
item.description: With other measures failing to halt rising prices in cities, some Chinese are hoping that a hinted-at property tax can rein in the real estate market. But opposition is likely among the wealthy and powerful.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: A visitor photographing a model of Beijing at the Beijing Planning Exhibition Hall, a museum showcasing the city's development.
